H0.text: Lateral continuity is the geological principle exemplified by the same rock layers being visible on opposite sides of the Grand Canyon and having been deposited simultaneously.

H1.text: Width continuity is the geological concept illustrated by the fact that the same rock layers are visible on opposite sides of the Grand Canyon and were deposited simultaneously.

H2.text: Bilateral continuity is the example of the same rock layers being visible on opposite sides of the Grand Canyon, indicating they were deposited simultaneously.

H3.text: Directly continuity is the example of the same rock layers visible on opposite sides of the Grand Canyon that were deposited simultaneously.

A4.text: The emerging scientific consensus is that the canyon is made up of multiple segments which formed at different times and eventually connected to become the waterway now traversed by the Colorado River.

A5.text: The major geologic exposures in the Grand Canyon range in age from the two-billion-year-old Vishnu Schist at the bottom of the Inner Gorge to the 270-million-year-old Kaibab Limestone on the Rim.

A6.text: Catholic priest Nicholas Steno established the theoretical basis for stratigraphy when he introduced the law of superposition, the principle of original horizontality and the principle of lateral continuity in a 1669 work on the fossilization of organic remains in layers of sediment.

A7.text: There are usually some gaps in the sequence called unconformities which represent periods where no new sediments were laid down, or when earlier sedimentary layers were raised above sea level and eroded away.

A8.text: Erosion removes most deposited sediment shortly after deposition.
